name: 4-n-propylbenzenesulfonyl chloride
Reason: 4-n-propylbenzenesulfonyl chloride has a melting point that we can predict by considering its structural components: (1) The basic unit for comparison is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The introduction of a propyl group (C3H7) increases the molecular weight and size, which generally raises the melting point. However, the sulfonyl group (–SO2–) introduces a polar functional group, which can participate in hydrogen bonding, lowering the melting point by approximately -10°C. The chlorine atom (Cl) also introduces a polar functional group, which can participate in hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by approximately +5°C. Summing these changes: Benzene base (5.5°C), propyl group (C3H7) (20°C), and sulfonyl group (–SO2–) (–10°C), and chlorine atom (Cl) (5°C).
